awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Biometric IoT system for First Responders
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to reduce injuries and costs due to overexertion and heat strain in firefighting through a real-time, biometric monitoring system and accompanying analysis tools. This system collects each firefighter's vital signs and sends the data to authorized commanders for real-time strategic decision-making. By receiving access to life-critical information, commanders can make informed decisions on the allocation of key resources during the hectic scene of an emergency. Every year over one million firefighters risk their lives to protect others. Almost 60% of the deaths in firefighting are caused by overexertion and stress, which can induce heart attacks as well as other serious medical issues. Around 70,000 firefighting injuries occur each year, and associated costs total over $7 billion annually.  The proposed system can be easily adapted to serve other first responders, such as military personnel, industrial workers, and others with occupational risk.

The proposed project will improve the occupational safety of first responders through the research and development of the following components:  1) An improved biometric collection wearable; 2) software used by the biometric monitoring system; 3) a location-monitoring tool; 4) algorithms to estimate sleep quality, fatigue, and detect symptoms for certain diseases, and improve exertion and core-body temperature estimates. 5) network improvement solutions allowing first responders in remote areas to utilize biometric monitoring tools. All five objectives will consist of multiple pilot studies with ongoing research and development that will incorporate crucial feedback from end-users. It is expected that the outcomes of this project will demonstrate a significant reduction in firefighter injuries, paving the way for a clear return on investment for partnering fire and emergency services.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Firefighting is chaotic; every year over one million firefighters risk their lives to protect others. Over 50% of the deaths in firefighting are caused by overexertion and stress, which can induce heart attacks as well as other serious medical issues. Furthermore, around 80,000 firefighting injuries occur each year in the US, each costing $97,000 on average. In total, injuries from firefighting totaled $7.8 billion in 2004.

 

One of the primary goals of this project was to research and develop technology to enhance the safety of our firefighters. Firefighting equipment does not include access to vital sign data in real-time, which could warn firefighters when they are overexerting themselves. To help fire departments prevent overexertion injuries and deaths, FireHUD developed a system to provide firefighters, incident commanders, and outside officials with real-time access to physiological data. With real-time access to physiological status, firefighters can now detect signs of overexertion, stress, and fatigue. This has allowed incident commanders to make well-informed decisions, such as when to rotate personnel or adjust tasks to prevent overexertion.

 

In addition to improving safety, FireHUD has also yielded financial benefits for participating fire departments. With a decrease in injuries and improved overall health among firefighters, there has been a noticeable reduction in the medical costs incurred by these departments. This cost-saving effect allows fire departments to allocate their budgets more efficiently, ultimately benefiting the community they serve.

 

The FireHUD project has not only enhanced firefighter safety but has also contributed to scientific knowledge in various fields. The IoT (Internet of Things) system used by FireHUD collects, standardizes, and disseminates data from firefighters. This data has become a valuable resource for researchers and experts from a multitude of fields, ranging from industrial safety to the military. These experts use this data to gain a better understanding of how the human body responds to extreme conditions and how wearables can measure these responses. The outcomes of this research have the potential to lead to advancements in firefighting techniques and equipment, as well as broader applications in industry, military, and other high-stress and physically demanding professions.
